Award.AwardTitle: Realtime GHz-Wide Spectrum Sensing and Acquisition Using the Sparse FFT
Award.AbstractNarration:
A GHz-wide radio spectrum sensing device capable of real-time, cheap, and low-power measurements will be made. The hardware will build on recent advances in the area of sparse Fourier transforms, which show that one can capture the frequency representation of a sparse signal without sampling it at the Nyquist rate. Preliminary results from a feasibility study show it is possible to recover GHz of bandwidth using a few low-speed low-power analog-to-digital converters similar to those used in inexpensive Wi-Fi cards.

The research enables efficient spectrum utilization and scalable spectrum monitoring, and hence can help the government in managing this important resource. Further, realtime GHz spectrum sensing can help detecting radar signals, which are hard to detect using existing technologies. This could open up large swaths of spectrum for sharing, which would stimulate innovations in the mobile and wireless domain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The wireless spectrum is an expensive and scarce resource. Hence, methods and technologies that improve spectrum usage are highly desirable. The project has developed technologies that enhance spectrum usage by leveraging the theory of sparse analysis, particularly the sparse Fourier Transform. In particular, we have develop a variety of new technologies for communication and sensing including: 1) BigBand: a tool for efficient and low-cost spectrum sensing, 2) LTEye, a tool for producing temporal and spatial analytics of LTE networks, 3) Caraoke, an e-toll transponder network for smart cities, 4) R2-F2, a technique for inferring wireless channels without receiver feedback,  5) Agile-Link, a beam alignment technology for millimeter wave networks, and 6) Chorus, a highly scalable distributed MIMO system. 

The technologies developed herein promise to improve wireless data rates, and enable new applications such as virtual reality and smart cities. The research has also contributed to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students. The research findings were disseminated via publications at the most prestigious venues, presentations at conferences, workshops, and summer schools,  and industry collaboration. The work received the best paper award at ACM SIGCOMM'16. The research also created connections and bridges between three fields: computer science theory, wireless networks and systems, and circuit design.
